I am myſelf, at this inſtant, in a ſtate of inexpreſſible embarraſſment; Miſs Sterling, I know, is extremely diſconcerted too; and unleſs you will oblige me with the aſſiſtance of your friendſhip, I foreſee the ſpeedy progreſs of diſcontent and animoſity through the whole family.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What the deuce is all this? I don't underſtand a ſingle ſyllable.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: In one word then—it will be abſolutely impoſſible for me to fulfill my engagements in regard to Miſs Sterling.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: How, Sir John? Do you mean to put an affront upon my family? What! refuſe to—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Be aſſured, Sir, that I neither mean to affront, nor forſake your family.—My only fear is, that you ſhould deſert me; for the whole happineſs of my life depends on my being connected with your family by the neareſt and tendereſt ties in the world.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Why, did not you tell me, but a moment ago, that it was abſolutely impoſſible for you to marry my daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: True.—But you have another daughter, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Well?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Who has obtained the moſt abſolute dominion over my heart. I have already declared my paſſion to her; nay, Miſs Sterling herſelf is alſo apprized of it, and if you will but give a ſanction to my preſent addreſſes, the uncommon merit of Miſs Sterling will no doubt recommend her to a perſon of equal, if not ſuperior rank to myſelf, and our families may ſtill be allied by my union with Miſs Fanny.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p:
Mighty fine, truly! Why, what the plague do you make of us, Sir John? Do you come to market for my daughters, like ſervants at a ſtatute-fair? Do you think that I will ſuffer you, or any man in the world, to come into my houſe, like the
Grand Signior, and throw the handkerchief firſt to one, and then to t'other, juſt as he pleaſes? Do you think I drive a kind of African ſlave-trade with them? and—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: A moment's patience, Sir! Nothing but the exceſs of my paſſion for Miſs Fanny ſhou'd have induced me to take any ſtep that had the leaſt appearance of diſreſpect to any part of your family; and even now I am deſirous to atone for my tranſgreſſion, by making the moſt adequate compenſation that lies in my power.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Compenſation! what compenſation can you poſſibly make in ſuch a caſe as this, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Come, come, Mr. Sterling; I know you to be a man of ſenſe, a man of buſineſs, a man of the world. I'll deal frankly with you; and you ſhall ſee that I do not deſire a change of meaſures for my own gratification, without endeavouring to make it advantageous to you.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What advantage can your inconſtancy be to me, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll tell you, Sir.—You know that by the articles at preſent ſubſiſting between us, on the day of my marriage with Miſs Sterling, you agree to pay down the groſs ſum of eighty thouſand pounds.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Well!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Now if you will but conſent to my waving that marriage—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I agree to your waving that marriage? Impoſſible, Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I hope not, Sir; as on my part, I will agree to wave my right to thirty thouſand pounds of the fortune I was to receive with her.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Thirty thouſand, d'ye ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes, Sir; and accept of Miſs Fanny with fifty thouſand, inſtead of fourſcore.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Fifty thouſand— [pauſing.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Inſtead of fourſcore.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Why,—why,—there may be ſomething in that.—Let me ſee; Fanny with fifty thouſand inſtead of Betſey with fourſcore—But how can this be, Sir John?—For you know I am to pay this money into the hands of my Lord Ogleby; who, I believe—between you and me, Sir John,—is not overſtocked with ready money at preſent; and threeſcore thouſand of it, you know, is to go to pay off the preſent incumbrances on the eſtate, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: That objection is eaſily obviated.—Ten of the twenty thouſand, which would remain as a ſurplus of the fourſcore, after paying off the mortgage, was intended by his Lordſhip for my uſe, that we might ſet off with ſome little eclat on our marriage; and the other ten for his own.—Ten thouſand pounds therefore I ſhall be able to pay you immediately; and for the remaining twenty thouſand you ſhall have a mortgage on that part of the eſtate which is to be made over to me, with whatever ſecurity you ſhall require for the regular payment of the intereſt, 'till the principal is duly diſcharged.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Why—to do you juſtice, Sir John, there is ſomething fair and open in your propoſal; and ſince I find you do not mean to put an affront upon the family—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nothing was ever farther from my thoughts, Mr. Sterling.—And after all, the whole affair is nothing extraordinary—ſuch things happen every day—and as the world has only heard generally of a treaty between the families, when this marriage takes place, nobody will be the wiſer, if we have but diſcretion enough to keep our own counſel.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: True, true; and ſince you only transfer from one girl to the other, it is no more than transferring ſo much ſtock, you know.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: The very thing.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Odſo! I had quite forgot. We are reckoning without our hoſt here. There is another difficulty—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You alarm me. What can that be?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I can't ſtir a ſtep in this buſineſs without conſulting my ſiſter Heidelberg.—The family has very great expectations from her, and we muſt not give her any offence.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But if you come into this meaſure, ſurely ſhe will be ſo kind as to conſent—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I don't know that—Betſey is her darling, and I can't tell how far ſhe may reſent any ſlight that ſeems to be offered to her favourite niece.—However, I'll do the beſt I can for you.—You ſhall go and break the matter to her firſt, and by that time that I may ſuppoſe that your rhetorick has prevailed on her to liſten to reaſon, I will ſtep in to reinforce your arguments.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll fly to her immediately: you promiſe me your aſſiſtance?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ten thouſand thanks for it! and now ſucceſs attend me![going.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Harkee, Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Not a word of the thirty thouſand to my ſiſter, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Oh, I am dumb, I am dumb, Sir. [going.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: You remember it is thirty thouſand.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To be ſure I do.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: But Sir John!—one thing more. [Sir John returns.] My Lord muſt know nothing of this ſtroke of friendſhip between us.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Not for the world.—Let me alone! let me alone![offering to go.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: [holding him.]—And when every thing is agreed, we muſt give each other a bond to be held faſt to the bargain.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: To be ſure. A bond by all means! a bond, or whatever you pleaſe. [Exit haſtily.

I ſhould have thought of more conditions—he's in a humour to give me every thing—Why, what mere children are your fellows of quality; that cry for a plaything one minute, and throw it by the next! as changeable as the weather, and as uncertain as the ſtocks.—Special fellows to drive a bargain! and yet they are to take care of the intereſt of the nation truly!—Here does this whirligig man of faſhion offer to give up thirty thouſand pounds in hard money, with as much indifference as if it was a china orange.—By this mortgage, I ſhall have a hold on his Terrafirma, and if he wants more money, as he certainly will,—let him have children by my daughter or no, I ſhall have his whole eſtate in a net for the benefit of my family.—Well; thus it is, that the children of citizens, who have acquired fortunes, prove perſons of faſhion; and thus it is, that perſons of faſhion, who have ruined their fortunes, reduce the next generation to cits. [Exit.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Heidelberg, and Miſs Sterling.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: This is your gentle-looking, ſoft-ſpeaking, ſweet-ſmiling, affable Miſs Fanny for you!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: My Miſs Fanny! I diſclaim her. With all her arts ſhe never could inſinuat herſelf into my good graces—and yet ſhe has a way with her, that deceives man, woman, and child, except you and me, niece.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: O ay; ſhe wants nothing but a crook in her hand, and a lamb under her arm, to be a perfect picture of innocence and ſimplicity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Juſt as I was drawn at Amſterdam, when I went over to viſit my huſband's relations.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p:
And then ſhe's ſo mighty good to ſervants—pray, John, do this—pray, Tom, do that—thank
you, Jenny—and then ſo humble to her relations—to be ſure, Papa!—as my Aunt pleaſes—my Siſter knows beſt—But with all her demureneſs and humility ſhe has no objection to be Lady Melvil, it ſeems, nor to any wickedneſs that can make her ſo.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: She Lady Melville? Compoſe yourſelf, Niece! I'll ladyſhip her indeed:—a little creepin, cantin—She ſhan't be the better for a farden of my money. But tell me, child, how does this intriguing with Sir John correſpond with her partiality to Lovewell? I don't ſee a concatunation here.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: There I was deceived, Madam. I took all their whiſperings and ſtealing into corners to be the mere attraction of vulgar minds; but, behold! their private meetings were not to contrive their own inſipid happineſs, but to conſpire againſt mine.—But I know whence proceeds Mr. Lovewell's reſentment to me. I could not ſtoop to be familiar with my father's clerk, and ſo I have loſt his intereſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: My ſpurrit to a T.—My dear child! [kiſſing her.]—Mr. Heidelberg loſt his election for member of parliament, becauſe I would not demean myſelf to be ſlobbered about by drunken ſhoemakers, beaſtly cheeſemongers, and greaſy butchers and tallow-chandlers. However, Niece, I can't help diffuring a little in opinion from you in this matter. My experunce and ſagucity makes me ſtill ſuſpect, that there is ſomething more between her and that Lovewell, notwithſtanding this affair of Sir John—I had my eye upon them the whole time of breakfaſt.—Sir John, I obſerved, looked a little confounded, indeed, though I knew nothing of what had paſſed in the garden. You ſeemed to ſit upon thorns too: but Fanny and Mr. Lovewell made quite another-gueſs ſort of a figur; and were as perfet a pictur of two diſtreſt lovers, as if it had been drawn by Raphael Angelo.—As to Sir John and Fanny, I want a matter of fact.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Matter of fact, Madam! Did not I come unexpectedly upon them? Was not Sir John kneeling at her feet, and kiſſing her hand? Did not he look all love, and ſhe all confuſion? Is not that matter of fact? And did not Sir John, the moment that Papa was called out of the room to the lawyermen, get up from breakfaſt, and follow him immediately? And I warrant you that by this time he has made propoſals to him to marry my ſiſter—Oh, that ſome other perſon, an earl, or a duke, would make his addreſſes to me, that I might be revenged on this monſter!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Be cool, child! you ſhall be Lady Melvil, in ſpite of all their caballins, if it coſts me ten thouſand pounds to turn the ſcale. Sir John may apply to my brother, indeed; but I'll make them all know who governs in this fammaly.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: As I live, Madam, yonder comes Sir John. A baſe man! I can't endure the ſight of him. I'll leave the room this inſtant. [diſordered.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Poor thing! Well, retire to your own chamber, child; I'll give it him, I warrant you; and by and by I'll come, and let you know all that has paſt between us.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Pray do, Madam!— [looking back.]—A vile wretch![Exit in a rage.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your moſt obedient humble ſervant, Madam![bowing very reſpectfully.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Your ſervant, Sir John![dropping a half-curtſy, and pouting.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Miſs Sterling's manner of quitting the room on my approach, and the viſible coolneſs of your behaviour to me, Madam, convince me that ſhe has acquainted you with what paſt this morning.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I am very ſorry, Sir John, to be made acquainted with any thing that ſhould induce me to change the opinon, which I could always wiſh to entertain of a perſon of quallaty. [pouting.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: It has always been my ambition to merit the beſt opinion from Mrs. Heidelberg; and when ſhe comes to weigh all circumſtances, I flatter myſelf—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: You do flatter yourſelf, if you imagine that I can approve of your behaviour to my niece, Sir John.—And give me leave to tell you, Sir John, that you have been drawn into an action much beneath you, Sir John; and that I look upon every injury offered to Miſs Betty Sterling, as an affront to myſelf, Sir John. [warmly.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I would not offend you for the world, Madam! but when I am influenced by a partiality for another, however ill-founded, I hope your diſcernment and good ſenſe will think it rather a point of honour to renounce engagements, which I could not fulfil ſo ſtrictly as I ought; and that you will excuſe the change in my inclinations, ſince the new object, as well as the firſt, has the honour of being your niece, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I diſclaim her as a niece, Sir John; Miſs Sterling diſclaims her as a ſiſter, and the whole fammaly muſt diſclaim her, for her monſtrus baſeneſs and treachery.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Indeed ſhe has been guilty of none, Madam. Her hand and heart are, I am ſure, entirely at the diſpoſal of yourſelf, and Mr. Sterling.
And if you ſhould not oppoſe my inclinations, I am ſure of Mr. Sterling's conſent, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Quite certain, Madam.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: [behind.] So! they ſeem to be coming to terms already. I may venture to make my appearance.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: To marry Fanny?[Sterling advances by degrees.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: My brother has given his conſent, you ſay?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: In the moſt ample manner, with no other reſtriction than the failure of your concurrence, Madam.— [ſees Sterling.]—Oh, here's Mr. Sterling, who will confirm what I have told you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: What! have you conſented to give up your own daughter in this manner, brother?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Give her up! no, not give her up, ſiſter; only in caſe that you—Zounds, I am afraid you have ſaid too much, Sir John. [apart to Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Yes, yes. I ſee now that it is true enough what my niece told me. You are all plottin and caballin againſt her.—Pray, does Lord Ogleby know of this affair?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I have not yet made him acquainted with it, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: No, I warrant you. I thought ſo.—And ſo his Lordſhip and myſelf truly, are not to be conſulted 'till the laſt.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What! did not you conſult my Lord? Oh, fie for ſhame, Sir John!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay, but Mr. Sterling—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: We, who are the perſons of moſt conſequence and experunce in the two fammalies, are to know nothing of the matter, 'till the whole is as good as concluded upon. But his Lordſhip, I am ſure, will have more generoſaty than to countenance ſuch a perceeding—And I could not have expected ſuch behavour from a perſon of your quallaty, Sir John.—And as for you, brother—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Nay, nay, but hear me, ſiſter!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I am perfetly aſhamed of you—Have you no ſpurrit? no more concern for the honour of our fammaly than to conſent—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Conſent?—I conſent!—As I hope for mercy, I never gave my conſent. Did I conſent, Sir John?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Not abſolutely, without Mrs. Heidelberg's concurrence. But in caſe of her approbation—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, I grant you, if my ſiſter approved.—But that's quite another thing, you know.— [to Mrs. Heidelberg.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Your ſiſter approve, indeed!—I thought you know her better, brother Sterling!—What! approve of having your eldeſt daughter returned upon your hands, and exchanged for the younger?—I am ſurprized how you could liſten to ſuch a ſcandalus propoſal.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I tell you, I never did liſten to it.—Did not I ſay that I would be governed entirely by my ſiſter, Sir John?—And unleſs ſhe agreed to your marrying Fanny—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I agree to his marrying Fanny? abominable! The man is abſolutely out of his ſenſes.—Can't that wiſe head of yours foreſee the conſequence of all this, brother Sterling? Will Sir John take Fanny without a fortune? No.—After you have ſettled the largeſt part of your property on your youngeſt daughter, can there be an equal portion left for the eldeſt? No.—Does not this overturn the whole ſyſtum of the fammaly? Yes, yes, yes. You know I was always for my niece Betſey's marrying a perſon of the very firſt quallaty. That was my maxum. And, therefore, much the largeſt ſettlement was of courſe to be made upon her.—As for Fanny, if ſhe could, with a fortune of twenty or thirty thouſand pounds, get a knight, or a member of parliament, or a rich common-council-man for a huſband, I thought it might do very well.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But if a better match ſhould offer itſelf, why ſhould not it be accepted, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: What! at the expence of her elder ſiſter! Oh fie, Sir John!—How could you bear to hear of ſuch an indignaty, brother Sterling?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I! nay, I ſhan't hear of it, I promiſe you.—I can't hear of it indeed, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p:
But you have heard of it, brother Sterling. You know you have; and ſent Sir John
to propoſe it to me. But if you can give up your daughter, I ſhan't forſake my niece, I aſſure you. Ah! if my poor dear Mr. Heidelberg, and our ſweet babes had been alive, he would not have behaved ſo.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Did I, Sir John? nay ſpeak!—Bring me off, or we are ruined. [apart to Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Why, to be ſure, to ſpeak the truth—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: To ſpeak the truth, I'm aſhamed of you both. But have a care what you are about, brother! have a care, I ſay. The lawyers are in the houſe, I hear; and if every thing is not ſettled to my liking, I'll have nothing more to ſay to you, if I live theſe hundred years.—I'll go over to Holland, and ſettle with Mr. Vanderſpracken, my poor huſband's firſt couſin; and my own fammaly ſhall never be the better for a farden of my money, I promiſe you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I thought ſo. I knew ſhe never would agree to it.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: 'Sdeath, how unfortunate! What can we do, Mr. Sterling?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Nothing.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What! muſt our agreement break off, the moment it is made then?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: It can't be helped, Sir John. The family, as I told you before, have great expectations from my ſiſter; and if this matter proceeds, you hear yourſelf that ſhe threatens to leave us.—My brother Heidelberg was a warm man; a very warm man; and died worth a Plumb at leaſt; a Plumb! ay, I warrant you, he died worth a Plumb and a half.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Well; but if I—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p:
And then, my ſiſter has three or four very good mortgages, a deal of money in the three percents. and old South-Sea annuities, beſides large concerns in the Dutch and French funds.—The
greateſt part of all this ſhe means to leave to our family.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I can only ſay, Sir—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Why, your offer of the difference of thirty thouſand, was very fair and handſome to be ſure, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Nay, but I am even willing to—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, but if I was to accept it againſt her will, I might loſe above a hundred thouſand; ſo, you ſee, the ballance is againſt you, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But is there no way, do you think, of prevailing on Mrs. Heidelberg to grant her conſent?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I am afraid not.—However, when her paſſion is a little abated—for ſhe's very paſſionate—you may try what can be done: but you muſt not uſe my name any more, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Suppoſe I was to prevail on Lord Ogleby to apply to her, do you think that would have any influence over her?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I think he would be more likely to perſuade her to it, than any other perſon in the family. She has a great reſpect for Lord Ogleby. She loves a lord.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I'll apply to him this very day.—And if he ſhould prevail on Mrs. Heidelberg, I may depend on your friendſhip, Mr. Sterling?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I ſhall be glad to oblige you, when it is in my power; but as the account ſtands now, you ſee it is not upon the figures. And ſo your ſervant, Sir John. [Exit.

What a ſituation am I in!—Breaking off with her whom I was bound by treaty to marry; rejected by the object of my affections; and embroiled with this turbulent woman, who governs the whole family.—And yet oppoſition, inſtead of ſmothering, increaſes my inclination. I muſt have her. I'll apply immediately to Lord Ogleby; and if he can but bring
over the aunt to our party, her influence will overcome the ſcruples and delicacy of my dear Fanny, and I ſhall be the happieſt of mankind. [Exit.

div.head: SCENE I. A room.
div.stage: Enter Sterling, Mrs. Heidelberg, and Miſs Sterling.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: WHAT! will you ſend Fanny to town, ſiſter?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: To-morrow morning. I've given orders about it already.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Poſitively.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: But conſider, ſiſter, at ſuch a time as this, what an odd appearance it will have.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Not half ſo odd, as her behaviour, brother.—This time was intended for happineſs, and I'll keep no incendaries here to deſtroy it. I inſiſt on her going off to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: I'm afraid this is all your doing, Betſey.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: No indeed, Papa. My aunt knows that it is not.—For all Fanny's baſeneſs to me, I am ſure I would not do, or ſay any thing to hurt her with you or my aunt for the world.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Hold your tongue, Betſey!—I will have my way.—When ſhe is packed off, every thing will go on as it ſhould do.—Since they are at their intrigues, I'll let them ſee that we can act with vigur on our part; and the ſending her out of the way ſhall be the purlimunary ſtep to all the reſt of my perceedings.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Well, but ſiſter—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p:
It does not ſignify talking, brother Sterling, for I'm reſolved to be rid of her, and I will.
—Come along, child! [to Miſs Sterling]—The poſtſhay ſhall be at the door by ſix o'clock in the morning; and if Miſs Fanny does not get into it, why I will, and ſo there's an end of the matter. [bounces out with Miſs Sterling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: One word more, brother Sterling!—I expect that you will take your eldeſt daughter in your hand, and make a formal complaint to Lord Ogleby of Sir John Melvil's behaviour.—Do this, brother; ſhew a proper regard for the honour of your fammaly yourſelf, and I ſhall throw in my mite to the raiſing of it. If not—but now you know my mind. So act as you pleaſe, and take the conſequences. [Exit.

The devil's in the woman for tyranny—mothers, wives, miſtreſſes, or ſiſters, they always will govern us.—As to my ſiſter Heidelberg, ſhe knows the ſtrength of her purſe, and domineers upon the credit of it.—"I will do this"—and "you ſhall do that"—and "you muſt do t'other, or elſe the fammaly ſhan't have a farden of"— [mimicking.]—So abſolute with her money!—but to ſay the truth, nothing but money can make us abſolute, and ſo we muſt e'en make the beſt of her.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What! Mademoiſelle Fanny to be ſent away!—Why?—Wherefore?—What's the meaning of all this?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Je ne ſcais pas.—I know noting of it.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
It can't be; it ſhan't be. I proteſt againſt the meaſure. She's a fine girl, and I had much rather that the reſt of the family were annihilated
than that ſhe ſhould leave us.—Her vulgar father, that's the very abſtract of 'Change-Alley—the aunt, that's always endeavouring to be a fine lady—and the pert ſiſter, for ever ſhewing that ſhe is one, are horrid company indeed, and without her would be intolerable. Ah, la petite Fanchon! ſhe's the thing. Is n't ſhe, Cant?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Dere is very good ſympatie entre vous, and dat young lady, mi Lor.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll not be left among theſe Goths and Vandals, your Sterlings, your Heidelbergs, and Devilbergs—If the goes, I'll poſitively go too.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: In de ſame poſt-chay, mi Lor? You have no object to dat I believe, nor Mademoiſelle neider too—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Prithee hold thy fooliſh tongue, Cant. Does thy Swiſs ſtupidity imagine that I can ſee and talk with a fine girl without deſires?—My eyes are involuntarily attracted by beautiful objects—I fly as naturally to a fine girl—

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: As de fine girl to you, my Lor, ha, ha, ha; you fly togedre like un pair de pigeons.—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Like un pair de pigeons— [mocks him.]—Vousetes un ſot, Monſ. Canton—Thou art always dreaming of my intrigues, and never ſeeſt me badiner, but you ſuſpect miſchief, you old fool, you.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I am fool, I confeſs, but not always fool in dat, my Lor, he, he, he.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: He, he, he.—Thou art incorrigible, but thy abſurdities amuſe one—Thou art like my rappee here, [takes out his box.] a moſt ridiculous ſuperfluity, but a pinch of thee now and then is a moſt delicious treat.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: You do me great honeur, my Lor.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: 'Tis fact, upon my Thou art properly my cephalick ſnuff, and art no bad medicine againſt megrims, vertigoes, and profound thinking—ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Your flatterie, my Lor, vil make me too prode.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The girl has ſome little partiality for me, to be ſure: but prithee, Cant, is not that Miſs Fanny yonder?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: [looking with a glaſs.] En veritè, 'tis ſhe, my Lor—'tis one of de pigeons,—de pigeons d'amour.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Don't be ridiculous, you old monkey. [ſmiling.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I am monkeè, I am ole, but I have eye, I have ear, and a little underſtand, now and den.—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Taiſez vous bête!

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Elle vous attend, my Lor.—She vil make a love to you.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Will ſhe? Have at her then! A fine girl can't oblige me more.—Egad, I find myſelf a little enjouée—come along, Cant! ſhe is but in the next walk—but there is ſuch a deal of this damned crinkum-crankum, as Sterling calls it, that one ſees people for half an hour before one can get to them—Allons, Monſ. Canton, allons donc!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: My dear Fanny, I cannot bear your diſtreſs; it overcomes all my reſolutions, and I am prepared for the diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: But how can it be effected before my departure?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p:
I'll tell you.—Lord Ogleby ſeems to entertain a viſible partiality for you; and notwithſtanding the peculiarities of his behaviour, I am ſure that he is humane at the bottom. He is vain to an exceſs; but withall extremely good-natured, and would do any thing to recommend himſelf to a lady.—Do you open the whole affair of our marriage to him immediately. It will come with more irreſiſtible perſuaſion
from you than from myſelf; and I doubt not but you'll gain his friendſhip and protection at once.—His influence and authority will put an end to Sir John's ſollicitations, remove your aunt's and ſiſter's unkindneſs and ſuſpicions, and, I hope, reconcile your father and the whole family to our marriage.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Heaven grant it! Where is my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I have heard him and Canton ſince dinner ſinging French ſongs under the great walnut-tree by the parlour door. If you meet with him in the garden, you may diſcloſe the whole immediately.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Dreadful as the taſk is, I'll do it.—Any thing is better than this continual anxiety.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: By that time the diſcovery is made, I will appear to ſecond you.—Ha! here comes my Lord.—Now, my dear Fanny, ſummon up all your ſpirits, plead our cauſe powerfully, and be ſure of ſucceſs.— [going.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Ah, don't leave me!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Nay, you muſt let me.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Well; ſince it muſt be ſo, I'll obey you, if I have the power. Oh Lovewell!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Conſider, our ſituation is very critical. To-morrow morning is fixt for your departure, and if we loſe this opportunity, we may wiſh in vain for another.—He approaches—I muſt retire.—Speak, my dear Fanny, ſpeak, and make us happy![Exit.
Good heaven, what a ſituation am I in! what ſhall I do? what ſhall I ſay to him? I am all confuſion.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
To ſee ſo much beauty ſo ſolitary, Madam, is a ſatire upon mankind, and 'tis fortunate that one man has broke in upon your reverie for the credit of our ſex.—I ſay one, Madam, for poor
Canton here, from age and infirmities, ſtands for nothing.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Noting at all, inteed.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip does me great honour.—I had a favour to requeſt, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: A favour, Madam!—To be honoured with your commands, is an inexpreſſible favour done to me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: If your Lordſhip could indulge me with the honour of a moment's—What is the matter with me?[aſide.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The girl's confus'd—he!—here's ſomething in the wind faith—I'll have a tete-a-tete with her—allez vous en![to Canton.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I go—ah, pauvre Mademoiſelle! my Lor, have pitié upon de poor pigeone!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll knock you down Cant, if you're impertinent. [ſmiling.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Den I mus avay— [ſhuffles along.]—You are moſh pleaſe, for all dat. [Aſide, and exit.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I ſhall ſink with apprehenſion. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What a ſweet girl!—ſhe's a civiliz'd being, and atones for the barbariſm of the reſt of the family.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: My Lord! I— [She curtſeys, and bluſhes.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: [addreſſing her.] I look upon it, Madam, to be one of the luckieſt circumſtances of my life, that I have this moment the honour of receiving your commands, and the ſatisfaction of confirming with my tongue, what my eyes perhaps have but too weakly expreſſed—that I am literally—the humbleſt of your ſervants.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I think myſelf greatly honoured, by your Lordſhip's partiality to me; but it diſtreſſes me, that I am obliged in my preſent ſituation to apply to it for protection.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
I am happy in your diſtreſs, Madam, becauſe it gives me an opportunity to ſhew my 〈◊〉 . Beauty to me, is a religion, in which I was born and
bred a bigot, and would die a martyr.—I'm in tolerable ſpirits, faith![aſide.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: There is not perhaps at this moment a more diſtreſſed creature than myſelf. Affection, duty, hope, deſpair, and a thouſand different ſentiments, are ſtruggling in my boſom; and even the preſence of your Lordſhip, to whom I have flown for protection, adds to my preplexity.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Does it, Madam?—Venus forbid!—My old fault; the devil's in me, I think, for perplexing young women. [aſide and ſmiling.] Take courage, Madam! dear Miſs Fanny, explain.—You have a powerful advocate in my breaſt, I aſſure you—my heart, Madam—I am attached to you by all the laws of ſympathy, and delicacy.—By my honour, I am.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Then I will venture to unburthen my mind.—Sir John Melvil, my Lord, by the moſt miſplaced, and miſtimed declaration of affection for me, has made me the unhappieſt of women.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: How, Madam! Has Sir John made his addreſſes to you?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: He has, my Lord, in the ſtrongeſt terms. But I hope it is needleſs to ſay, that my duty to my father, love to my ſiſter, and regard to the whole family, as well as the great reſpect I entertain for your Lordſhip, [curtſeying] made me ſhudder at his addreſſes.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Charming girl!—Proceed, my dear Miſs Fanny, proceed!

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: In a moment—give me leave, my Lord!—But if what I have to diſcloſe ſhould be received with anger or diſpleaſure—

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Impoſſible, by all the tender powers!—Speak, I beſeech you, or I ſhall divine the cauſe before you utter it.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p:
Then, my Lord, Sir John's addreſſes are not only ſhocking to me in themſelves, but are more
particularly diſagreeable to me at this time, as—as— [heſitating.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: As what, Madam?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: As—pardon my confuſion—I am intirely devoted to another.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: If this is not plain, the devil's in it— [aſide.] But tell me, my dear Miſs Fanny, for I muſt know; tell me the how, the when, and the where—Tell me—

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: My Lor, my Lor, my Lor!—

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Damn your Swiſs impertinence! how durſt you interrupt me in the moſt critical melting moment that ever love and beauty honoured me with?

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I demande pardonne, my Lor! Sir John Melvil, my Lor, ſent me to beg you to do him the honour to ſpeak a little to your Lorſhip.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: I'm not at leiſure—I'm buſy—Get away, you ſtupid old dog, you Swiſs raſcal, or I'll—

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Fort bien, my Lor.— [Cant. goes out tipto • .

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: By the laws of gallantry, Madam, this interruption ſhould be death; but as no puniſhment ought to diſturb the triumph of the ſofter paſſions, the criminal is pardoned and diſmiſſed—Let us return, Madam, to the higheſt luxury of exalted minds—a declaration of love from the lips of beauty.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: The entrance of a third perſon has a little relieved me, but I cannot go thro' with it—and yet I muſt open my heart with a diſcovery, or it will break with its burthen.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: What paſſion in her eyes! I am alarmed to agitation. [aſide.]—I preſume, Madam, (and as you have flattered me, by making me a party concerned, I hope you'll excuſe the preſumption) that—

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Do you excuſe my making you a party concerned, my Lord, and let me intereſt your heart in my behalf, as my future happineſs or miſery in a great meaſure depend—

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: Upon me, Madam?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Upon you, my Lord. [ſighs.

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: There's no ſtanding this: I have caught the infection—her tenderneſs diſſolves me. [ſighs.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: And ſhould you too ſeverely judge of a raſh action which paſſion prompted, and modeſty has long concealed—

sp.speaker: L. Ogle.
sp.p: [taking her hand.] Thou amiable creature—command my heart, for it is vanquiſhed—Speak but thy virtuous wiſhes, and enjoy them.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I cannot, my Lord—indeed, I cannot—Mr. Lovewell muſt tell you my diſtreſſes—and when you know them—pity and protect me!— [Exit, in tears.

How the devil could I bring her to this? It is too much—too much—I can't bear it—I muſt give way to this amiable weakneſs— [wipes his eyes.] My heart overflows with ſympathy, and I feel every tenderneſs I have inſpired— [ſtifles the tear.] How blind have I been to the deſolation I have made!—How could I poſſibly imagine that a little partial attention and tender civilities to this young creature ſhould have gathered to this burſt of paſſion! Can I be a man and withſtand it? No—I'll ſacrifice the whole ſex to her.—But here comes the father, quite apropos. I'll open the matter immediately, ſettle the buſineſs with him, and take the ſweet girl down to Ogleby-houſe to-morrow morning—But what the devil! Miſs Sterling too! What miſchief's in the wind now?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: My Lord, your ſervant! I am attending my daughter here upon rather a diſagreeable affair. Speak to his Lordſhip, Betſey!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Your eyes, Miſs Sterling—for I always read the eyes of a young lady—betray ſome little emotion—What are your commands, Madam?

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: I have but too much cauſe for my emotion, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I cannot commend my kinſman's behaviour, Madam. He has behaved like a falſe knight, I muſt confeſs. I have heard of his apoſtacy. Miſs Fanny has informed me of it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Miſs Fanny's baſeneſs has been the cauſe of Sir John's inconſtancy.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Nay, now, my dear Miſs Sterling, your paſſion tranſports you too far. Sir John may have entertain'd a paſſion for Miſs Fanny, but believe me, my dear Miſs Sterling, believe me, Miſs Fanny has no paſſion for Sir John. She has a paſſion, indeed, a moſt tender paſſion. She has opened her whole ſoul to me, and I know where her affections are placed. [conceitedly.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Not upon Mr. Lovewell, my Lord; for I have great reaſon to think that her ſeeming attachment to him, is, by his conſent, made uſe of as a blind to cover her deſigns upon Sir John.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Lovewell! No, poor lad! She does not. think of him. [ſmiling.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Have a care, my Lord, that both the families are not made the dupes of Sir John's artifice and my ſiſter's diſſimulation! You don't know her—indeed, my Lord, you don't know her—a baſe, inſinuating, perſidious!—It is too much—She has been beforehand with me, I perceive. Such unnatural behaviour to me!—But ſince I ſee I can have no redreſs, I am reſolved that ſome way or other I will have revenge. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: This is fooliſh work, my Lord▪

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I have too much ſenſibility to bear the tears of beauty.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: It is touching indeed, my Lord—and very moving for a father.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
To be ſure, Sir!—You muſt be diſtreſt beyond meaſure!—Wherefore, to divert your too exquiſite
feelings, ſuppoſe we change the ſubject, and proceed to buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: With all my heart, my Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: You ſee, Mr. Sterling, we can make no union in our families by the propos'd marriage.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: And very ſorry I am to ſee it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Have you ſet your heart upon being allied to our houſe, Mr. Sterling?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: 'Tis my only wiſh, at preſent, my omnium, as I may call it.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Your wiſhes ſhall be fulfill'd.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Shall they, my Lord!—but how—how?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll marry in your family.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What! my ſiſter Heidelberg?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: You throw me into a cold ſweat, Mr. Sterling. No, not your ſiſter—but your daughter.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: My daughter!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Fanny!—now the murder's out!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What you, my Lord?—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Yes—I, I, Mr. Sterling!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: No, no, my Lord—that's too much. [ſmiling.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Too much?—I don't comprehend you.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What, you, my Lord, marry my Fanny!—Bleſs me, what will the folks ſay?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Why, what will they ſay?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: That you're a bold man, my Lord—that's all.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Mr. Sterling, this may be city wit for ought I know—Do you court my alliance?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: To be ſure, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Then I'll explain.—My nephew won't marry your eldeſt daughter—nor I neither—Your youngeſt daughter won't marry him—I will marry your youngeſt daughter—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What! with a younger daughter's fortune, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p:
With any fortune, or no fortune at all, Sir. Love is the idol of my heart, and the daemon intereſt ſinks before him. So, Sir, as I ſaid before,
I will marry your youngeſt daughter; your youngeſt daughter will marry me.—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Who told you ſo, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Her own ſweet ſelf, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Yes, Sir: our affection is mutual; your advantage double and treble—your daughter will be a Counteſs directly—I ſhall be the happieſt of beings—and you'll be father to an Earl inſtead of a Baronet.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: But what will my ſiſter ſay?—and my daughter?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll manage that matter—nay, if they won't conſent, I'll run away with your daughter in ſpite of you.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Well ſaid, my Lord!—your ſpirit's good—I wiſh you had my conſtitution!—but if you'll venture, I have no objection, if my ſiſter has none.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll anſwer for your ſiſter, Sir. Apropos! the lawyers are in the houſe—I'll have articles drawn, and the whole affair concluded to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Very well: and I'll diſpatch Lovewell to London immediately for ſome freſh papers I ſhall want, and I ſhall leave you to manage matters with my ſiſter. You muſt excuſe me, my Lord, but I can't help laughing at the match—He! he! he! what will the folks ſay?[Exit.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What a fellow am I going to make a father of?—He has no more feeling than the poſt in his warehouſe—But Fanny's virtues tune me to rapture again, and I won't think of the reſt of the family.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I beg your Lordſhip's pardon, my Lord; are you alone, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: No, my Lord, I am not alone! I am in company, the beſt company.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I never was in ſuch exquiſite enchanting company ſince my heart firſt conceived, or my ſenſes taſted pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Where are they, my Lord?[looking about.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: In my mind, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: What company have you there, my Lord?[ſmiling.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: My own ideas, Sir, which ſo croud upon my imagination, and kindle it to ſuch a delirium of extaſy, that wit, wine, muſick, poetry, all combined, and each perfection, are but mere mortal ſhadows of my felicity.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I ſee that your Lordſhip is happy, and I rejoice at it.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: You ſhall rejoice at it, Sir; my felicity ſhall not ſelfiſhly be confined, but ſhall ſpread its influence to the whole circle of my friends. I need not ſay, Lovewell, that you ſhall have your ſhare of it.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Shall I, my Lord?—then I underſtand you—you have heard—Miſs Fanny has inform'd you—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: She has—I have heard, and ſhe ſhall be happy—'tis determin'd.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Then I have reached the ſummit of my wiſhes—And will your Lordſhip pardon the folly?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: O yes, poor creature, how could ſhe help it?—'Twas unavoidable—Fate and neceſſity.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: It was indeed, my Lord—Your kindneſs diſtracts me.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: And ſo it did the poor girl, faith.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: She trembled to diſcloſe the ſecret, and declare her affections?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The world, I believe, will not think her affections ill placed.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: —[bowing.]— You are too good, my Lord.—And do you really excuſe the raſhneſs of the action?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: From my very ſoul, Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Your generoſity overpowers me.— [bowing.]—I was afraid of her meeting with a cold reception.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.l: More fool you then.
Who pleads her cauſe with never-failing beauty,
Here finds a full redreſs. [ſtrikes his breaſt.
sp.p: She's a fine girl, Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Her beauty, my Lord, is her leaſt merit. She has an underſtanding—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Her choice convinces me of that.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: —[bowing.]— That's your Lordſhip's goodneſs. Her choice was a diſintereſted one.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: No—no—not altogether—it began with intereſt, and ended in paſſion.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, if you were acquainted with her goodneſs of heart, and generoſity of mind, as well as you are with the inferior beauties of her face and perſon—

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I am ſo perfectly convinced of their exiſtence, and ſo totally of your mind touching every amiable particular of that ſweet girl, that were it not for the cold unfeeling impediments of the law, I would marry her to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: My Lord!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I would, by all that's honourable in man, and amiable in woman.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Marry her!—Who do you mean, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Miſs Fanny Sterling, that is—the Counteſs of Ogleby that ſhall be.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I am aſtoniſhed.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Why, could you expect leſs from me?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I did not expect this, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Trade and accounts have deſtroyed your feeling.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: No, indeed, my Lord. [ſighs.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The moment that love and pity entered my breaſt, I was reſolved to plunge into matrimony, and ſhorten the girl's tortures—I never do any thing by halves; do I, Lovewell?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: No, indeed, my Lord— [ſighs.]—What an accident!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What's the matter, Lovewell? thou ſeem'ſt to have loſt thy faculties. Why don't you wiſh me joy, man?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: O, I do, my Lord. [ſighs.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: She ſaid, that you would explain what ſhe had not power to utter—but I wanted no interpreter for the language of love.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But has your Lordſhip conſidered the conſequences of your reſolution?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: No, Sir; I am above conſideration, when my deſires are kindled.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But conſider the conſequences, my Lord, to your nephew, Sir John.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Sir John has conſidered no conſequences himſelf, Mr. Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Mr. Sterling, my Lord, will certainly refuſe his daughter to Sir John.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Sir John has already refuſed Mr. Sterling's daughter.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But what will become of Miſs Sterling, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What's that to you?—You may have her, if you will.—I depend upon Mr. Sterling's cityphiloſophy, to be reconciled to Lord Ogleby's being his ſon-in-law, inſtead of Sir John Melvil, Baronet. Don't you think that your maſter may be brought to that, without having recourſe to his calculations? Eh, Lovewell!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But, my Lord, that is not the queſtion.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Whatever is the queſtion, I'll tell you my anſwer.—I am in love with a fine girl, whom I reſolve to marry.
What news with you, Sir John?—You look all hurry and impatience—like a meſſenger after a battle.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p:
After a battle, indeed, my Lord.—I have this day had a ſevere engagement, and wanting your Lordſhip as an auxiliary, I have at laſt muſtered
up reſolution to declare, what my duty to you and to myſelf have demanded from me ſome time.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: To the buſineſs then, and be as conciſe as poſſible; for I am upon the wing—eh, Lovewell?[he ſmiles, and Lovewell bows.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I find 'tis in vain, my Lord, to ſtruggle againſt the force of inclination.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Very true, Nephew—I am your witneſs, and will ſecond the motion—ſhan't I, Lovewell?[ſmiles, and Lovewell bows.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip's generoſity encourages me to tell you—that I cannot marry Miſs Sterling.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I am not at all ſurpriz'd at it—ſhe's a bitter potion, that's the truth of it; but as you were to ſwallow it, and not I, it was your buſineſs, and not mine—any thing more?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: But this, my Lord—that I may be permitted to make my addreſſes to the other ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: O yes—by all means—have you any hopes there, Nephew?—Do you think he'll ſucceed, Lovewell?[ſmiles, and winks at Lovewell.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I think not, my Lord. [gravely.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I think ſo too, but let the fool try.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Will your Lordſhip favour me with your good offices to remove the chief obſtacle to the match, the repugnance of Mrs Heidelberg?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Mrs. Heidelberg▪—Had not you better begin with the young lady firſt? it will ſave you a great deal of trouble; won't it, Lovewell?— [ſmiles.]—but do what you pleaſe, it will be the ſame thing to me—won't it, Lovewell?— [conceitedly.]—Why don't you laugh at him?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I do, my Lord. [forces a ſmile.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And you Lordſhip will endeavour to prevail on Mrs. Heidelberg to conſent to my marriage with Miſs Fanny?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I'll go and ſpeak to Mrs. Heidelberg, about the adorable Fanny, as ſoon as poſſible.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Your generoſity tranſports me.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Poor fellow, what a dupe! he little thinks who's in poſſeſſion of the town. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And your Lordſhip is not offended at this ſeeming inconſtancy.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt. Miſs Fanny's charms will even excuſe infidelity—I look upon women as the ferae naturae,—lawfull game—and every man who is qualified, has a natural right to purſue them; Lovewell as well as you, and I as well as either of you.—Every man ſhall do his beſt, without offence to any—what ſay you, kinſmen?

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: You have made me happy, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And me, I aſſure you, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: And I am ſuperlatively ſo—allons donc—to horſe and away, boys!—you to your affairs, and I to mine—ſuivons l'amour![ſings.

div.head: SCENE I. Fanny's apartment.
div.stage: Enter Lovewell and Fanny—followed by Betty.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: WHY did you come ſo ſoon, Mr. Lovewell? the family is not yet in bed, and Betty certainly heard ſomebody liſtening near the chamber-door.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My miſtreſs is right, Sir! evil ſpirits are abroad; and I am ſure you are both too good, not to expect miſchief from them.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But who can be ſo curious, or ſo wicked?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I think we have wickedneſs, and curioſity enough in this family, Sir, to expect the worſt.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p:
I do expect the worſt.—Prithee, Betty, return to the outward door, and liſten if you hear
any body in the gallery; and let us know directly.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I warrant you, Madam—the Lord bleſs you both![Exit.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: What did my father want with you this evening?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: He gave me the key of his cloſet, with orders to bring from London ſome papers relating to Lord Ogleby.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: And why did not you obey him?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Becauſe I am certain that his Lordſhip has open'd his heart to him about you, and thoſe papers are wanted merely on that account—but as we ſhall diſcover all to-morrow, there will be no occaſion for them, and it would be idle in me to go.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Hark!—hark! bleſs me, how I tremble!—I feel the terrors of guilt—indeed, Mr. Lovewell, this is too much for me.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: And for me too, my ſweet Fanny. Your apprehenſions make a coward of me.—But what can alarm you? your aunt and ſiſter are in their chambers, and you have nothing to fear from the reſt of the family.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I fear every body, and every thing, and every moment—My mind is in continual agitation and dread;—indeed, Mr. Lovewell, this ſituation may have very unhappy conſequences. [weeps.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p:
But it ſhan't—I would rather tell our ſtory this moment to all the houſe, and run the riſque of maintaining you by the hardeſt labour, than ſuffer you to remain in this dangerous perplexity.—What! ſhall I ſacrifice all my beſt hopes and affections, in your dear health and ſafety, for the mean, and in ſuch a caſe, the meaneſt conſideration—of our fortune! Were we to be abandon'd by all our relations, we have that in our hearts and minds, will weigh againſt the moſt affluent circumſtances.—I ſhould not have propos'd the ſecrecy of our marriage, but for your ſake; and with hopes that the
moſt generous ſacrifice you have made to love and me, might be leſs injurious to you, by waiting a lucky moment of reconciliation.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Huſh! huſh! for heav'n ſake, my dear Lovewell, don't be ſo warm!—your generoſity gets the better of your prudence; you will be heard, and we ſhall be diſcovered.—I am ſatisfied, indeed I am.—Excuſe this weakneſs, this delicacy—this what you will.—My mind's at peace—indeed it is—think no more of it, if you love me!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: That one word has charm'd me, as it always does, to the moſt implicit obedience; it would be the worſt of ingratitude in me to diſtreſs you a moment. [kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [in a low voice.] I'm ſorry to diſturb you.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Ha! what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Have you heard any body?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have, and they have heard you too, or I am miſtaken—if they had ſeen you too, we ſhould have been in a fine quandary.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Prithee don't prate now, Betty!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: What did you hear?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I was preparing myſelf, as uſual, to take me a little nap.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: A nap!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, a nap; for I watch much better ſo than wide awake; and when I had wrap'd this handkerchief round my head, for fear of the earach, from the key-hole I thought I heard a kind of a ſort of a buzzing, which I firſt took for a gnat, and ſhook my head two or three times, and went ſo with my hand—

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Well—well—and ſo—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: And ſo, Madam, when I heard Mr. Lovewell a little loud, I heard the buzzing louder too—and pulling off my handkerchief ſoftly—I could hear this ſort of noiſe— [makes an indiſtinct noiſe like ſpeaking.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Well, and what did they ſay?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Oh! I cou'd not underſtand a word of what was ſaid.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: The outward door is lock'd?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Yes; and I bolted it too, for fear of the worſt.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Why did you? they muſt have heard you, if they were near.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: And I did it on purpoſe, Madam, and cough'd a little too, that they might not hear Mr. Lovewell's voice—when I was ſilent, they were ſilent, and ſo I came to tell you.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: What ſhall we do?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Fear nothing; we know the worſt▪ it will only bring on our cataſtrophe a little too ſoon—but Betty might fancy this noiſe—ſhe's in the conſpiracy, and can make a man of a mouſe at any time.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I can diſtinguiſh a man from a mouſe, as well as my betters—I am ſorry you think ſo ill of me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: He compliments you, don't be a fool!—Now you have ſet her tongue a running, ſhe'll mutter for an hour. [to Lovewell.] I'll go and hearken myſelf. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'll turn my back upon no girl, for ſincerity and ſervice. [half aſide, and muttering.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: Thou art the firſt in the world for both; and I will reward you ſoon, Betty, for one and the other.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I'm not marcenary neither—I can live on a little, with a good carreter.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: All ſeems quiet—ſuppoſe, my dear, you go to your own room—I ſhall be much eaſier then—and to-morrow we will be prepared for the diſcovery.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: You may diſcover, if you pleaſe; but, for my part, I ſhall ſtill be ſecret. [half aſide, and muttering.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p:
Should I leave you now,—if they ſtill are upon the watch, we ſhall loſe the advantage of our delay.—Beſides, we ſhould conſult upon to-morrow's buſineſs,—Let Betty go to her own room, and lock
the outward door after her; we can faſten this; and when ſhe thinks all ſafe, ſhe may return and let me out as uſual.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Shall I, Madam?

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Do! let me have my way to-night, and you ſhall command me ever after.—I would not have you ſurprized here for the world.—Pray leave me! I ſhall be quite myſelf again, if you will oblige me.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: I live only to oblige you, my ſweet Fanny! I'll be gone this moment. [going.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Let us liſten firſt at the door, that you may not be intercepted.—Betty ſhall go firſt, and if they lay hold of her—

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: They'll have the wrong ſow by the ear, I can tell them that. [going haſtily.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: Softly—ſoftly—Betty! don't venture out, if you hear a noiſe.—Softly, I beg of you!—See, Mr. Lovewell, the effects of indiſcretion!

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: But love, Fanny, makes amends for all.

head.hi: SCENE changes to a gallery, which leads to ſeveral bed-chambers.

div.stage: Enter Miſs Sterling, leading Mrs. Heidelberg in a night-cap.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: This way, dear Madam, and then I'll tell you all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Nay, but Niece—conſider a little—don't drag me out in this figur—let me put on my fly-cap!—if any of my Lord's fammaly, or the counſellors at law, ſhould be ſtirring, I ſhould be perdigus diſconcarted.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: But, my dear Madam, a moment is an age, in my ſituation. I am ſure my ſiſter has been plotting my diſgrace and ruin in that chamber—O ſhe's all craft and wickedneſs!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p:
Well, but ſoftly, Betſey!—you are all in emotion—your mind is too much fluſtrated—you
can neither eat nor drink, nor take your natural reſt—compoſe yourſelf, child; for if we are not as waryſome as they are wicked, we ſhall diſgrace ourſelves and the whole fammaly.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: We are diſgrac'd already, Madam—Sir John Melvil has forſaken me; my Lord cares for nobody but himſelf; or, if for any body, it is my ſiſter; my father, for the ſake of a better bargain, would marry me to a 'Change-broker; ſo that if you, Madam, don't continue my friend—if your forſake me—if I am to loſe my beſt hopes and conſolation—in your tenderneſs—and affect—ions—I had better—at once—give up the matter—and let my ſiſter enjoy—the fruits of her treachery—trample with ſcorn upon the rights of her elder ſiſter, the will of the beſt of aunts, and the weakneſs of a too intereſted father. [ſhe pretends to be burſting into tears all this ſpeech.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Don't Betſey—keep up your ſpurrit—I hate whimpering—I am your friend—depend upon me in every partickler—but be compoſed, and tell me what new miſchief you have diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: I had no deſire to ſleep, and would not undreſs myſelf, knowing that my Machiavel ſiſter would not reſt till ſhe had broke my heart:—I was ſo uneaſy that I could not ſtay in my room, but when I thought that all the houſe was quiet, I ſent my maid to diſcover what was going forward; ſhe immediately came back and told me that they were in high conſultation; that ſhe had heard only, for it was in the dark, my ſiſter's maid conduct Sir John Melvil to her miſtreſs, and then lock the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: And how did you conduct yourſelf in this dalimma?

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p:
I return'd with her, and could hear a man's voice, though nothing that they ſaid diſtinctly; and you may depend upon it, that Sir John is now in that room, that they have ſettled the matter, and
will run away together before morning, if we don't prevent them.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Why the brazen ſlut! has ſhe got her ſiſter's huſband (that is to be) lock'd up in her chamber! at night too?—I tremble at the thoughts▪

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Huſh, Madam! I hear ſomething.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: You frighten me—let me put on my fly cap—I would not be ſeen in this figur for the world.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: 'Tis dark, Madam; you can't be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I proteſt there's a candle coming, and a man too.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Nothing but ſervants; let us retire a moment![they retire.

div.stage: Enter Bruſh half drunk, laying hold of the Chambermaid, who has a candle in her hand.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Be quiet Mr. Bruſh; I ſhall drop down with terror!

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: But my ſweet, and moſt amiable chambermaid, if you have no love, you may hearken to a little reaſon; that cannot poſſibly do your virtue any harm.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: But you will do me harm, Mr. Bruſh, and a great deal of harm too—pray let me go—I am ruin'd if they hear you—I tremble like an aſp.

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: But they ſhan't hear us—and if you have a mind to be ruin'd, it ſhall be the making of your fortune, you little ſlut, you!—therefore I ſay it again, if you have no love—hear a little reaſon!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: I wonder at your impurence, Mr. Bruſh, to uſe me in this manner; this is not the way to keep me company, I aſſure you.—You are a town rake I ſee, and now you are a little in liquor, you fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p:
Nothing, by heav'ns, but your frowns, moſt amiable chamber-maid; I am a little electrified, that's the truth on't; I am not uſed to drink Port, and
your maſter's is ſo heady, that a pint of it overſets a claret-drinker.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Don't be rude! bleſs me!—I ſhall be ruin'd—what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: I'll take care of you, by all that's honourable.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: You are a baſe man to uſe me ſo—I'll cry out, if you don't let me go—that is Miſs Sterling's chamber, that Miſs Fanny's, and that Madam Heidelberg's. [pointing.

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: And that my Lord Ogleby's, and that my Lady what d'ye call'em: I don't mind ſuch folks when I'm ſober, much leſs when I am whimſical—rather above that too.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: More ſhame for you, Mr. Bruſh!—you terrify me—you have no modeſty.

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: O but I have, my ſweet ſpider-bruſher!—for inſtance, I reverence Miſs Fanny—ſhe's a moſt delicious morſel and fit for a prince—with all my horrors of matrimony, I could marry her myſe;f—but for her ſiſter—

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: There, there, Madam, all in a ſtory!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Bleſs me, Mr. Bruſh!—I heard ſomething!

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: Rats, I ſuppoſe, that are gnawing the old timbers of this execrable old dungeon—If it was mine, I would pull it down, and fill your fine canal up with the rubbiſh; and then I ſhould get rid of two damn'd things at once.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Law! law! how you blaſpheme!—we ſhall have the houſe upon our heads for it.

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: No, no, it will laſt our time—but as I was faying, the eldeſt ſiſter—Miſs Jezabel—

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Is a fine young lady for all your evil tongue.

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: No—we have ſmoak'd her already; and unleſs ſhe marries our old Swiſs, ſhe can have none of us—no, no, ſhe wont do—we are a little too nice.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: You're a monſtrous rake, Mr. Bruſh, and don't care what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: Why, for that matter, my dear, I am a little inclined to miſchief; and if you won't have pity upon me, I will break open that door and raviſh Mrs. Heidelberg.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: [coming forward.] There's no bearing this—you profligate monſter!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Ha! I am undone!

sp.speaker: Bruſh.
sp.p: Zounds! here ſhe is, by all that's monſtrous. [runs off.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: A fine diſcourſe you have had with that fellow!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: And a fine time of night it is to be here with that drunken monſter.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: What have you, to ſay for yourſelf?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: I can ſay nothing.—I am ſo frighten'd, and ſo aſham'd—but indeed I am vartuous—I am vartuous indeed.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Well, well—don't tremble ſo; but tell us what you know of this horrable plot here.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: We'll forgive you, if you'll diſcover all.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Why, Madam—don't let me betray my fellow ſervants—I ſhan't ſleep in my bed, if I do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Then you ſhall ſleep ſomewhere elſe to-morrow night.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: O dear!—what ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Tell us this moment,—or I'll turn you out of doors directly.

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Why our butler has been treating us below in his pantry—Mr. Bruſh forc'd us to make a kind of a holiday night of it.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Holiday! for what?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Nay I only made one.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Well, well; but upon what account?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Becauſe, as how, Madam, there was a change in the family they ſaid,—that his honour, Sir John—was to marry Miſs Fanny inſtead of your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: And ſo you made a holiday for that.—Very fine!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: I did not make it, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: But do you know nothing of Sir John's being to run away with Miſs Fanny to-night?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: No, indeed, Ma'am!

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Nor of his being now locked up in my ſiſter's chamber?

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: No, as I hope for marcy, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Well, I'll put an end to all this directly—do you run to my brother Sterling—

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: Now, Ma'am!—'Tis ſo very late, Ma'am—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I don't care how late it is. Tell him there are thieves in the houſe—that the houſe is o'fire—tell him to come here immediately—go, I ſay!

sp.speaker: Ch. Maid.
sp.p: I will, I will, though I'm frighten'd out of my wits. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Do you watch here, my dear; and I'll put myſelf in order, to face them. We'll plot 'em, and counter-plot 'em too. [Exit into her chamber.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: I have as much pleaſure in this revenge, as in being made a counteſs!—Ha! they are unlocking the door.—Now for it![retires.

div.stage: Fanny's door is unlock'd—and Betty comes out with a candle. Miſs Sterling approaches her.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [calling within.] Sir, Sir!—now's your time—all's clear. [ſeeing Miſs Sterl.] Stay, ſtay—not yet—we are watch'd.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: And ſo you are, Madam Betty! [Miſs Sterling lays hold of her, while Betty locks the door, and puts the key in her pocket.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [turning round.] What's the matter, Madam?

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Nay, that you ſhall tell my father and aunt, Madam.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: I am no tell-tale, Madam, and no thief they'll get nothing from me.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p:
You have a great deal of courage,
Betty; and conſidering the ſecrets you have to keep, you have occaſion for it.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My miſtreſs ſhall never repent her good opinion of me, Ma'am.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What is all this? what's the matter? why am I diſturbed in this manner?

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: This creature, and my diſtreſſes, Sir, will explain the matter.

div.stage: Re-enter Mrs. Heidelberg, with another head-dreſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Now I'm prepar'd for the rancounter—well, brother, have you heard of this ſcene of wickedneſs?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Not I—but what is it? Speak!—I was got into my little cloſet—all the lawyers were in bed, and I had almoſt loſt my ſenſes in the confuſion of Lord Ogleby's mortgages, when I was alarm'd with a fooliſh girl, who could hardly ſpeak; and whether it's fire, or thieves, or murder, or a rape, I am quite in the dark.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: No, no, there's no rape, brother!—all parties are willing, I believe.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Who's in that chamber?[detaining Betty, who ſeemed to be ſtealing away.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: My miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: And who is with your miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: Why, who ſhould there be?

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Open the door then, and let us ſee!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: The door is open, Madam. [Miſs Sterling goes to the door.] I'll ſooner die than peach![Exit haſtily.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: The door's lock'd; and ſhe has got the key in her pocket.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: There's impudence, brother! piping hot from your daughter Fanny's ſchool!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: But, zounds! what is all this about? You tell me of a ſum total, and you don't produce the particulars.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Sir John Melvil is lock'd up in your daughter's bed-chamber.—There is the particular!

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: The devil he is?—That's bad!

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: And he has been there ſome time too.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ditto!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Ditto! worſe and worſe, I ſay. I'll raiſe the houſe, and expoſe him to my Lord, and the whole family.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: By no means! we ſhall expoſe ourſelves, ſiſter!—the beſt way is to inſure privately—let me alone!—I'll make him marry her to-morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Make him marry her! this is beyond all patience!—You have thrown away all your affection; and I ſhall do as much by my obedience: unnatural fathers, make unnatural children.—My revenge is in my own power, and I'll indulge it.—Had they made their eſcape, I ſhould have been expoſed to the deriſion of the world:—but the deriders ſhall be derided; and ſo—help! help, there! thieves! thieves!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Tit-for-tat, Betſey!—you are right, my girl.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Zounds! you'll ſpoil all—you'll raiſe the whole family,—the devil's in the girl.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: No, no; the devil's in you, brother. I am aſham'd of your principles.—What! would you connive at your daughter's being lock'd up with her ſiſter's huſband? Help! thieves! thieves! I ſay. [cries out.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Siſter, I beg you!—daughter, I command you.—If you have no regard for me, conſider yourſelves!—we ſhall loſe this opportunity of ennobling our blood, and getting above twenty per cent. for our money.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: What, by my diſgrace and my ſiſter's triumph! I have a ſpirit above ſuch mean conſiderations; and to ſhew you that it is not a low-bred, vulgar 'Change-Alley ſpirit—help! help! thieves! thieves! thieves! I ſay.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, ay, you may ſave your lungs—the houſe is in an uproar;—women at beſt have no diſcretion; but in a paſſion they'll fire a houſe, or burn themſelves in it, rather than not be revenged.

div.stage: Enter Canton, in a night-gown and ſlippers.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: Eh, diable! vat is de raiſon of dis great noiſe, this tintamarre?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Aſk thoſe ladies, Sir; 'tis of their making.
Bruſh! Bruſh!—Canton! where are you?—What's the matter? [rings a bell.] Where are you?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: 'Tis my Lord calls, Mr. Canton.

sp.speaker: Cant.
sp.p: I com, mi Lor!— [Exit Canton.] —[Lord Ogleby ſtill rings.
A light! a light here!—where are the ſervants? Bring a light for me, and my brothers.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Lights here! lights for the gentlemen![Exit Sterling.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: My brother feels, I ſee—your ſiſter's turn will come next.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let it go round, Madam! it is the only comfort I have left.

div.stage: Re-enter Sterling, with lights, before Serjeant Flower (with one boot and a ſlipper) and Traverſe.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: This way, Sir! this way, gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Serjeant Flower.
sp.p: Well, but, Mr. Sterling, no danger I hope.—Have they made a burglarious entry?—Are you prepar'd to repulſe them?—I am very much alarm'd about thieves at circuit-time.—They would be particularly ſevere with us gentlemen of the bar.

sp.speaker: Traverſe.
sp.p: No danger, Mr. Sterling?—No treſpaſs, I hope?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: None, gentlemen, but of thoſe ladies making.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p:
You'll be aſham'd to know, gentlemen, that all your labours and ſtudies about this
young lady are thrown away—Sir John Melvil is at this moment lock'd up with this lady's younger ſiſter.

sp.speaker: Serjeant Flower.
sp.p: The thing is a little extraordinary, to be ſure—but, why were we to be frighten'd out of our beds for this? Could not we have try'd this cauſe to-morrow morning?

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: But, Sir, by to-morrow morning, perhaps, even your aſſiſtance would not have been of any ſervice—the birds now in that cage would have flown away.

div.stage: Enter Lord Ogleby [in his robe de chambre, night cap &c.—leaning on Canton.]

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I had rather loſe a limb than my night's reſt—what's the matter with you all?

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: Ay, ay, 'tis all over!—Here's my Lord too.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: What is all this ſhrieking and ſcreaming?—Where's my angelick Fanny. She's ſafe, I hope!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Your angelick Fanny, my Lord, is lock'd up with your angelick nephew in that chamber.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: My nephew! then will I be excommunicated.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Your nephew, my Lord, has been plotting to run away with the younger ſiſter; and the younger ſiſter has been plotting to run away with your nephew: and if we had not watch'd them and call'd up the fammaly, they had been upon the ſcamper to Scotland by this time.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Look'ee, ladies!—I know that Sir John has conceiv'd a violent paſſion for Miſs Fanny; and I know too that Miſs Fanny has conceiv'd a violent paſſion for another perſon; and I am ſo well convinc'd of the rectitude of her affections, that I will ſupport them with my fortune, my honour, and my life.—Eh, ſhant I, Mr. Sterling? [ſmiling] what ſay you?—

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: [ſulkily.] To be ſure, my Lord.—Theſe bawling women have been the ruin of every thing. [aſide.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: But come, I'll end this buſineſs in a trice—if you, ladies, will compoſe yourſelves, and Mr. Sterling will inſure Miſs Fanny from violence, I will engage to draw her from her pillow with a whiſper thro' the keyhole.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: The horrid creatures!—I ſay, my Lord, break the door open.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Let me beg of your delicacy not to be too precipitate!—Now to our experiment![advancing towards the door.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Now, what will they do?—my heart will beat thro' my boſom.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: There's no occaſion for breaking open doors, my Lord; we have done nothing that we ought to be aſham'd of, and my miſtreſs ſhall face her enemies.— [going to unlock the door.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: There's impudence.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: The myſtery thickens. Lady of the bed-chamber! [to Betty] open the door, and intreat Sir John Melvil (for theſe ladies will have it that he is there,) to appear and anſwer to high crimes and miſdemeanors.—Call Sir John Melvil into the court!

div.stage: Enter Sir John Melvil, on the other ſide.

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: I am here, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Heyday!

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Aſtoniſhment!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: What is all this alarm and confuſion? there is nothing but hurry in the houſe; what is the reaſon of it?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Becauſe you have been in that chamber; have been! nay you are there at this moment, as theſe ladies have proteſted, ſo don't deny it—

sp.speaker: Traverſe.
sp.p: This is the cleareſt Alibi I ever knew, Mr. Serjeant.

sp.speaker: Flower.
sp.p: Luce clarius.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Upon my word, ladies, if you have often theſe frolicks, it would be really entertaining to paſs a whole ſummer with you. But come, [to Betty] open the door, and intreat your amiable miſtreſs to come forth, and diſpel all our doubts with her ſmiles.

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [opening the door.] Madam, you are wanted in this room. [pertly.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: You ſee ſhe's ready dreſs'd—and what confuſion ſhe's in!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: Ready to pack off, bag and baggage!—her guilt confounds her!—

sp.speaker: Flowers.
sp.p: Silence in the court, ladies!

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I am confounded, indeed, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Don't droop, my beauteous lilly! but with your own peculiar modeſty declare your ſtate of mind.—Pour conviction into their ears, and raptures into mine. [ſmiling.

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: I am at this moment the moſt unhappy—moſt diſtreſt—the tumult is too much for my heart—and I want the power to reveal a ſecret, which to conceal has been the misfortune and miſery of my—my— [faints away.

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: She faints; help, help! for the faireſt, and beſt of women!

sp.speaker: Betty.
sp.p: [running to her.] O my dear miſtreſs!—help, help, there!—

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: Ha! let me fly to her aſſiſtance.

div.stage: Lovewell ruſhes out from the chamber.

sp.speaker: Lovew.
sp.p: My Fanny in danger! I can contain no longer.—Prudence were now a crime; all other cares are loſt in this!—ſpeak, ſpeak, to me, my deareſt Fanny!—let me but hear thy voice, open your eyes, and bleſs me with the ſmalleſt ſign of life![during this ſpeech they are all in amazement.

sp.speaker: Miſs Sterl.
sp.p: Lovewell!—I am eaſy.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Heidel.
sp.p: I am thunderſtuck!

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: I am petrify'd!

sp.speaker: Sir John.
sp.p: And I undone!

sp.speaker: Fanny.
sp.p: [recovering.] O Lovewell!—even ſupported by thee, I dare not look my father nor his Lordſhip in the face.

sp.speaker: Sterl.
sp.p: What now! did not I ſend you to London, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lord Ogle.
sp.p: Eh!—What!—How's this?—by what right and title have you been half the night in that lady's bed-chamber?

sp.speaker: Lovew.
